events.title: Captain James Cook Reaches the Hawaiian Islands
events.description: Captain James Cook became the first European to visit the Hawaiian Islands, which he named the Sandwich Islands.
events.significance: This event marked the first recorded European contact with Hawaii, opening the islands to increased interaction and eventual integration into global maritime routes.

events.title: Paris Peace Conference Opens
events.description: Delegates from over 30 countries met in Paris to negotiate the peace treaties that would end World War I.
events.significance: The decisions made at this conference redefined national borders and set the stage for international relations in the 20th century, leading to the Treaty of Versailles.

events.title: Zookeeper Who Saved Jews During Holocaust Recognized
events.description: Zoo director Janusz Korczak refused to abandon the orphans in his care and died with them in Treblinka extermination camp (commemorated on January 18).
events.significance: Korczak's sacrifice symbolizes courage and humanity during the Holocaust, and he is remembered as a hero who protected children under dire circumstances.

events.title: Operation Desert Storm Begins
events.description: The U.S.-led coalition launched air strikes against Iraq, initiating the Gulf War to expel Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
events.significance: This marked the start of a major conflict in the Middle East with significant geopolitical implications for regional stability and international relations.

events.title: Socrates Dies
events.description: Greek classical philosopher Socrates died in Athens after being sentenced to death by poison for corrupting youth and impiety.
events.significance: Socrates is considered a foundational figure in Western philosophy, and his method of inquiry influenced centuries of thought.
